Sid Northern Ireland agrees power-sharing deal Gordon Brown hails historic deal see justice policing powers devolved Stormont 12 April * Henry McDonald <http://www.guardian.co.uk/profile/henrymcdonald> * guardian.co.uk <http://www.guardian.co.uk/> , Friday 5 February 2010 11.42 GMT * <http://www.guardian.co.uk/help/accessibility> Gordon Brown, Peter Robinson Martin McGuinness <http://static.guim.co.uk/sys- images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2010/2/5/1265368562294/Gordon-Brown-Peter-Robins-001.jpg> Gordon Brown, DUP leader, Peter Robinson, Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness (I r) talk press Northern Ireland power-sharing deal announced. Photograph: Julien Behal/PA UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773264 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773264 Date: 08/31/2015 Justice policing powers devolved Northern Ireland <http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/northernireland>'s power-sharing government 12 April historic deal agreed main parties "opens new chapter" decades violence, Gordon Brown said today. Standing alongside Irish counterpart, Brian Cowen, press conference Hillsborough Castle outside Belfast, prime minister said "inspirational" agreement Sinn Fein <http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/sinn-fein> Democratic Unionist party (DUP) <http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/dup> foundation lasting peace. The deal — finally agreed DUP <http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2010/feb/05/northern-ireland-dup-ulster- deal> last night described final piece jigsaw long search peace — comes two weeks round-the-clock negotiations brings end fears power-sharing government might collapse. It see policing justice powers devolved Westminster assembly within weeks includes new plans overseeing parades. Brown, travelled Belfast morning, said agreement possible "a new spirit mutual co-operation respect". The deal meets key Sinn Fein demand prevents republican party walking power-sharing executive. In return, DUP secured reforms way loyalist marches handled Northern Ireland, including abolition Parades Commission, body unionists regard biased favour nationalists. A cross-community vote held Stormont assembly 9 March policing justice powers devolved London 12 April. Brown told reporters: "The achievements great inspirational. This moment agreement belongs people Northern Ireland, people, ever future ... This last chapter long troubled story beginning new chapter decades violence, years talks, weeks stalemate." Cowen praised unionists nationalists making "fair balanced compromises" bridge divisions said quality negotiations meant "devolved institutions work". The Northern Ireland secretary, Shaun Woodward, said deal would isolate republican dissidents launched three separate gun bomb attacks police stations province last 10 days. The deal would "absolutely" make Northern Ireland safer place, said. The DUP leader, Peter Robinson, said agreement "will enduring time spent" forming it. Referring back Belfast Agreement 1998 <http://www.nio.gov.uk/the-agreement> negotiations bore fruit 11th hour, Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, described current deal rescue power-sharing "yet another good Friday". Jeffrey Donaldson told Guardian DUP's 36-strong assembly team unanimously favour deal. But Ulster Unionist party (UUP) yet officially back package allow assembly set legislation change way parades judged. A UUP spokeswoman said members wanted see proposed agreement giving response two governments. "We sight agreement signing it," said. The talks, centred Hillsborough Castle, outside Belfast, longest set continuous negotiations held near 20-year peace process. Sinn Fein accused DUP stalling transfer policing powers last three years feared failure find agreement could see collapse power-sharing government led two parties. The agreement finally came near midnight Stormont's parliament building. Earlier evening Sinn Fein said basis deal table giving DUP leadership time persuade party accept it. Robinson emerged meeting party colleagues confirm secured unanimous support proposals. Earlier week 14 DUP assembly members opposed proposed deal give unionists enough concessions. Robinson said would look gain support community smaller assembly parties deal. "We basis upon go forward recommend [the deal] party, parties Northern Ireland community. "An essential element Democratic Unionist Party's manifesto requirement community confidence; believe basis gaining confidence." However leader hardline Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV), Jim Allister, questioned 14 DUP rebels changed minds. The DUP faces struggle ward TUV threat forthcoming general election. Allister portray deal sell-out unionist principles sop republicanism. Sid Northern Ireland agrees power-sharing deal Gordon Brown hails historic deal see justice policing powers devolved Stormont 12 April * Henry McDonald <http://www.guardian.co.uk/profile/henrymcdonald> * guardian.co.uk <http://www.guardian.co.ukh , Friday 5 February 2010 11.42 GMT * <http://www.guardian.co.uk/help/accessibility> Gordon Brown, Peter Robinson Martin McGuinness <http://static.guim.co.uk/sys- images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2010/2/5/1265368562294/Gordon-Brown-Peter-Robins-001.jpg> Gordon Brown, DUP leader, Peter Robinson, Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness (I r) talk press Northern Ireland power-sharing deal announced. Photograph: Julien Behal/PA Justice policing powers devolved Northern Ireland <http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/northernireland>'s power-sharing government 12 April historic deal agreed main parties "opens new chapter" decades violence, Gordon Brown said today. Standing alongside Irish counterpart, Brian Cowen, press conference Hillsborough Castle outside Belfast, prime minister said "inspirational" agreement Sinn Fein <http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/sinn-fein> Democratic Unionist party (DUP) <http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/dup> foundation lasting peace. The deal — finally agreed DUP <http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2010/feb/05/northern-ireland-dup-ulster- deal> last night described final piece jigsaw long search peace — comes two weeks round-the-clock negotiations brings end fears power-sharing government might collapse. It see policing justice powers devolved Westminster assembly within weeks includes new plans overseeing parades. Brown, travelled Belfast morning, said agreement possible "a new spirit mutual co-operation respect". The deal meets key Sinn Fein demand prevents republican party walking power-sharing executive. In return, DUP secured reforms way loyalist marches handled Northern Ireland, including abolition Parades Commission, body unionists regard biased favour nationalists. A cross-community vote held Stormont assembly 9 March policing justice powers devolved London 12 April. Brown told reporters: "The achievements great inspirational. This moment agreement belongs people Northern Ireland, people, ever future ... Cowen praised unionists nationalists making "fair balanced compromises" bridge divisions said quality negotiations meant "devolved institutions work". The Northern Ireland secretary, Shaun Woodward, said deal would isolate republican dissidents launched three separate gun bomb attacks police stations province last 10 days. The deal would "absolutely" make Northern Ireland safer place, said. The DUP leader, Peter Robinson, said agreement "will enduring time spent" forming it. Referring back Belfast Agreement 1998 <http://www.nio.gov.uk/the-agreement> negotiations bore fruit 11th hour, Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, described current deal rescue power-sharing "yet another good Friday". Jeffrey Donaldson told Guardian DUP's 36-strong assembly team unanimously favour deal. But Ulster Unionist party (UUP) yet officially back package allow assembly set legislation change way parades judged. A UUP spokeswoman said members wanted see proposed agreement giving response two governments. "We sight agreement signing it," said. The talks, centred Hillsborough Castle, outside Belfast, longest set continuous negotiations held near 20-year peace process. Sinn Fein accused DUP stalling transfer policing powers last three years feared failure find agreement could see collapse power-sharing government led two parties. The agreement finally came near midnight Stormont's parliament building. Earlier evening Sinn Fein said basis deal table giving DUP leadership time persuade party accept it. Robinson emerged meeting party colleagues confirm secured unanimous support proposals. Earlier week 14 DUP assembly members opposed proposed deal give unionists enough concessions. However leader hardline Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV), Jim Allister, questioned 14 DUP rebels changed minds. "The deal hasn't changed, snowmen DUP, melted heat came on," Allister said. The DUP faces struggle ward TUV threat forthcoming general election. Allister portray deal sell-out unionist principles sop republicanism. Political dilemma: The executive decree establishing state urgency expires February 15 extended Parliament. Parliament fiercely critical Preval/Bellerive government since disaster, This leaves government dilemma handle extraordinary disaster needs (such declaring land public utility) February 15. UN SRSG Mullet encouraged Bellerive seek "full consensus" opposition "nothing short unanimity" would required address enormous challenges Haiti facing. Bellerive said GOH also evaluating upcoming elections constitutional reform, implied time reach decision matters. Preval address nation: The government going designate February 12 (the month anniversary quake) day national mourning President Preval make first formal address nation since disaster. They drafting speech part mourning part vision future. Preval wants announce ministries running usual. Ministries: The PM said Primature Ministry Planning moving old US Embassy building. The courts move old USAID building. The plan move number ministries Croix des Bouquets met little enthusiasm main line ministries. They prefer clear rubble properties downtown Port-au-Prince either build new buildings (EU offering finance) put temporary structures (Canada offering finance). From battlefields Vietnam hills Western Pennsylvania halls Congress, Jack Murtha lived Marine Corps credo "Semper Fidelis," never wavering faithful commitment country loved men women bravely defend her. In war peace, fought knew right, even unpopular. He fierce advocate working families struggling changing economy better health care equipment servicemembers. And course three decades Congress, became one nation's respected voices national security foreign policy. Presidents parties sought advice generations colleagues looked leadership wisdom. As Senator New York serving Armed Services Committee, I fortunate call Jack friend mentor. And Secretary State, I continued rely expertise judgment. I knew Jack would always shoot straight, like Marine was, never shy away difficult question tough fight. Today country lost decorated war hero distinguished public servant. The men women armed forces lost tireless champion. And people Pennsylvania's 12th district lost neighbor, advocate, true friend. My thoughts prayers Jack's beloved wife Joyce family. From: Peter Harrell To: Harrell, Peter E Sent: Sun Jan 24 14:56:20 2010 Subject: Conversation Bob Maguire Cheryl, I good conversation Bob afternoon. The major points wanted emphasize ones included emails you, including: "Rebalancing" Haitian development: Redevelopment occur nationwide encourage even distribution Haitian population. The international community rebuild Port-au-Prince expense rest country. Bob thinks nationwide rebuilding also reduce chances elite capture rebuilding effort, since elites strongly concentrated Port-au-Prince. • Transparency: Bob cautious throwing money problem. He thinks international community establish new norm transparency Haiti, example, ensure isn't widespread corruption, price gauging, grants monopolies, etc. • Link Haitian business community business communities: Bob thinks rebuilding done usual suspects Haitian business community, they'll simply build back country before. He recommends working bring foreign investors, linking foreign investors leading Haitian businessmen (e.g., business roundtable) socialize better business practices Haiti. • On issue legal authorities reconstruction: Bob recommends exploring whether presidential commission-like structures could empowered resolve legal problems likely arise barriers reconstruction. UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773522 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773522 Date: 08/31/2015 • Duration US presence: Bob cautioned Haitians would happy see long-term US military presence country, though would likely adverse reputational consequences hemisphere United States. Given hurricane season begin fall, Bob recommends draw down, make clear return needed. • Getting people work: Bob argued NGOs may best vehicles getting Haitians work (e.g., job training, etc.). In short, they're nice. Many Haitians never held regular job, unfamiliar showing time, etc. They'll need bit tough love discipline. Bob though ex-military might set right kind example. • Diaspora: Engaging diaspora clearly important, want support widespread repatriation diaspora NGO employees, reconstruction experts, etc., expense Haitians never left. This reinforces wage differentials social discontent returnees. • Conditional cash transfers: Bob thinks conditional cash transfer programs lot potential improve education delivery health services Haiti. A Development Policy Guided Objectives UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773691 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773691 Date: 08/31/2015 Even reconsider development architecture, vital development policy guided objectives rather organize government deliver development assistance. We focus big issues — food scarcity, poverty, disease, environmental degradation -- prevent economic growth large swath world's countries. Those objectives require strategies reflect needs countries helping rather vagaries budget process, often allocates funds response lobbying pressures, media interest, political favoritism. Country strategies based broad objectives also give us best chance avoid dependence arbitrary spending targets specific sectors. For example, promoting food security requires investments agricultural productivity, clean water, infrastructure, basic higher education, land titling, name factors. The Global Food Security Act, I authored Senator Casey Senator Kerry co-sponsored, reflects principles. The food price crisis occurred 2008 resulted culmination policy choices donor recipient governments decades-long period. That crisis wakeup call development community, international donors, policymakers worldwide. Because achieving food security must multi-sector endeavor goes beyond simply raising crop yields, U.S. policy must seek integrate variety approaches actors. At time, want delegate responsibility food security policy multiple departments. That could weaken already fractured foreign assistance structure. That bill designates USAID, broad development experience necessary, lead agency implement strategy. "Whole-of-Government" Perspective The term "whole-of-government" come vogue policy circles. To extent term underscores complexity development problems need apply talents diverse set agencies solution, useful descriptive. Our government must capacity draw expertise achieve vital development missions without artificial barriers erected agencies. Many agencies working together successfully development problems many parts world. But mistake term "whole-of-government" organizational strategy. Even multiple agencies making contributions, someone must charge, someone must coordinate activities involved, someone must take responsibility inefficiencies failures. This especially important development context highly fragmented aid system. The risk term "whole-of-government," used justify fragmentation preserve roles agencies justified. We also must careful whole-of-government concept re-define development series technical decisions — dig wells seeds plant soils. Such redefinition would devalue discipline development, many practitioners spent lifetime studying testing. We know long experience technical expertise must grounded understanding development. For example, agricultural advancement depends much reaching women farmers, building agriculture education, engaging civil society support rural development seed quality planting decisions. An integrated strategy come agency understands development separate discipline, Dr. Shah said. UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773691 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773691 Date: 08/31/2015 I believe starting point future design assistance programs status quo, rather period well-functioning well-resourced aid agency. Unity Purpose Instead accepting whole-of-government, organizational model, guiding narrative, I believe helpful way viewing development mission — "unity-of-purpose." We need unified around common purposes marshal appropriate level resources variety approaches. There situations call involvement multiple agencies direction one government entity. Reforming U.S. Foreign Assistance UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773693 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773693 Date: 08/31/2015 Reforming U.S. foreign assistance — substance architecture — priority Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Secretary Clinton stated: "I want USAID seen premier development agency world." I share sentiment. One basic questions respect foreign aid reform best strengthen capacity USAID run effective assistance programs. During last two decades, decision-makers made easy agency perform mission. Development resources declined precipitously 1990s reorganization initiatives resulted agency's loss evaluation, budget, policy capacity. There broad consensus among development experts loss functions USAID inhibiting success development programs. Our development efforts never effective agency houses development expertise cut relevant policy budget decisions. Events since 2001 spurred greater investments foreign assistance. But many resources located outside USAID. Roughly two dozen departments agencies taken aspects foreign assistance, including Department Defense Department Agriculture. The President advocated doubling foreign assistance time, announced new initiatives food security health. Given increased resources needed initiatives, crucial American people Congress confidence funds used efficiently. USAID must central role development policy decisions. If avoid inefficient experimentation, must capacity evaluate programs disseminate information best practices methods. That requires policy makers continue augmenting agency's staffing expertise. These principals reflected legislation Senator Kerry I introduced last year, S. 1524, Foreign Assistance Revitalization Accountability Act. The Administration initiated two separate studies — State Department's Quadrennial Diplomacy Development Review National Security Council's Presidential Study Directive Development — attempt make recommendations development programs better support U.S. foreign policy objectives. The QDDR completed fall uncertain when, if, know outcomes PSD. I eager review Administration's ideas ready. But meantime, Congress offering ideas improve government's development capacity. The Kerry-Lugar foreign assistance reform bill product well year research analysis Senators staffs. It strong support aid community. And co-sponsored bipartisan group 23 Senators, twelve members Foreign Relations Committee. This level backing bill related foreign assistance extremely rare. It provides opportunity build something approaching consensus issue. I hopeful Executive Branch recognize bill co-sponsored majority Senate Foreign Relations Committee nearly quarter full Senate given substantial weight review process. A strong development agency serves foreign policy guidance Secretary State, envisioned bill, best empower advance U.S. goals. A Development Policy Guided Objectives UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773693 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773693 Date: 08/31/2015 Even reconsider development architecture, vital development policy guided objectives rather organize government deliver development assistance. We focus big issues — food scarcity, poverty, disease, environmental degradation -- prevent economic growth large swath world's countries. Those objectives require strategies reflect needs countries helping rather vagaries budget process, often allocates funds response lobbying pressures, media interest, political favoritism. Country strategies based broad objectives also give us best chance avoid dependence arbitrary spending targets specific sectors. For example, promoting food security requires investments agricultural productivity, clean water, infrastructure, basic higher education, land titling, name factors. The Global Food Security Act, I authored Senator Casey Senator Kerry co-sponsored, reflects principles. The food price crisis occurred 2008 resulted culmination policy choices donor recipient governments decades-long period. That crisis wakeup call development community, international donors, policymakers worldwide. Because achieving food security must multi-sector endeavor goes beyond simply raising crop yields, U.S. policy must seek integrate variety approaches actors. At time, want delegate responsibility food security policy multiple departments. That could weaken already fractured foreign assistance structure. That bill designates USAID, broad development experience necessary, lead agency implement strategy. "Whole-of-Government" Perspective The term "whole-of-government" come vogue policy circles. To extent term underscores complexity development problems need apply talents diverse set agencies solution, useful descriptive. Our government must capacity draw expertise achieve vital development missions without artificial barriers erected agencies. Many agencies working together successfully development problems many parts world. But mistake term "whole-of-government" organizational strategy. Even multiple agencies making contributions, someone must charge, someone must coordinate activities involved, someone must take responsibility inefficiencies failures. This especially important development context highly fragmented aid system. The risk term "whole-of-government," used justify fragmentation preserve roles agencies justified. We also must careful whole-of-government concept re-define development series technical decisions — dig wells seeds plant soils. Such redefinition would devalue discipline development, many practitioners spent lifetime studying testing. We know long experience technical expertise must grounded understanding development. For example, agricultural advancement depends much reaching women farmers, building agriculture education, engaging civil society support rural development seed quality planting decisions. An integrated strategy come agency understands development separate discipline, Dr. Shah said. Original Message From: Mark J. Penn To: H Sent: Thu Jan 21 09:56:56 2010 Subject: FW: Mark Penn's latest Huffington Post blog: "Stopping Republican Comeback (Déjà Vu All Over Again)" Great internet speech based excerpts I seen — terrific. Here's piece I yesterday. The Huffington Post January 20, 2010 Strategy Corner: Stopping Republican Comeback (Déjà Vu All Over Again) Once initially popular Democratic president tries pass healthcare reform, raise taxes wealthy expand domestic spending. And voters send sharp signal want chart centrist course. As Yogi Berra said "It's déjà vu again." President Clinton's wakeup call came 1994 mid-term elections -- Obama's came year earlier yesterday's special election Massachusetts. In response similar situation, President Clinton fundamentally changed everything -- team, policies, overall direction message administration. He moved center balanced budget, welfare reform, policies helped concerned moms raise kids, leaving behind divisive bitterness first two years. As part new team then, I saw President Clinton consciously took presidency back centrist message presidential campaign relentlessly pursued swing voters; didn't go small, went vital center -- 24 million jobs balanced budget big accomplishments. President Obama plenty time turn around facing kind losses President Clinton did. But stopping Republican machine done basis words alone -- take actions results calm electorate. It also won't done basis stepped populist rhetoric. You can't make deals Wall Street, Pharma, major interest groups turn around make whipping boy credibility. No doubt fight White House many inside wanting go back equivalent "people vs. powerful." Only voters see White House powerful lurch would probably harshest electoral consequences next November. But Obama turn around keep country moving steady path change makes kind significant changes direction President Clinton did. It's getting trappings Washington said were. UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773929 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773929 Date: 08/31/2015 Here's five things President could now. 1) Agree full transparency health care hearings major reform areas -- Obama's original idea put C-SPAN right one. Then go major transparency government binge, seeking new ways bring people closer administration social networking online means. Make transparency action, theme. 2) Break health care components move step step. The problem health care one agrees solution bill longer lives, greater access greater efficiency people want. Break start easy stuff like electronic medical records first work harder parts year year. 3) Look ways genuinely bi-partisan instead seeking 60th vote deals compromise. Genuine bi-partisanship would given Republicans malpractice reform exchange public option -- don't invest opposition outcome, reason support it. Just looking one vote exercise deal making compromise live post-partisan promise. Obama's got call Republican leaders sit them, push away. 4) Put jobs front center -- failure earlier root discontent. The administration hit 10 per cent tripwire unemployment numbers center country dismal -- far worse Massachusetts. This means moving country forward new economic world, trying take backwards. Raising taxes another flash point much administration's support came upper income voters turned right wing, anti-intellectual campaigns Republicans. People need know strategy competing winning emerging global, high tech economy. 5) Don't afraid think small stuff -- helping people daily lives. Helping people deal new stresses modern life -- texting road many working well past 65 -- small thing. People afraid big, grandiose plans fear bankrupt country need see government also relating daily lives manageable, concrete ways. It's kind daily activism Democrats uniquely bring White House. This got part strategy returns us lower unemployment, lower deficits, restrained spending. There plenty time push back Republicans get heady. That day come Newt Gingrich shut government backfired. But right Republicans issue -- issue whether administration gone Washington whether reclaim centrist, people-oriented mantle brought town. And means taking administration back vital center fulfilling core promises -- greater transparency, less political posturing, true bi-partisanship, extreme focus jobs economy, government demonstrates daily really cares people. Sid CONFIDENTIAL February 12, 2010 For: Hillary From: Sid Re: Saudi Arabia I contact Chas Freeman, former ambassador Saudi Arabia, sent recent public speech subject. He says policy part toward end, King Abdullah's new university (KAUST) important initiative. He also relates atmosphere near toxic Obama's failure follow Cairo speech rebuff Netanyahu. Cynicism, best, pervasive among Saudi elite. Saudi Arabia: The End Progress without Change Remarks Sarasota Institute Lifetime Learning Ambassador Chas W. Freeman, Jr. (USFS, Ret.) Sarasota, Florida, February 11, 2010 I asked speak Kingdom Saudi Arabia. This topic I never addressed American audience. Why bother? We Americans reserve right strong opinions basis little knowledge. There countries better exemplify assertive ignorance foreign geography, history, culture Saudi Arabia. Most us UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773930 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773930 Date: 08/31/2015 convinced Saudis Muslim zealots, control world's oil prices, absurdly rich, anti-feminist, undemocratic. They hate values want destroy us. Talk radio confirms this. What needs said? On reflection, lot does. Neither caricature priori reasoning sound basis policy. A distorted view foreign realities precludes success dealing them. There much stake relationship Saudi Arabia. We ill afford get wrong. That country is, course, heartland Islam custodian world's largest oil reserves. It lies athwart transport routes Asia, Europe, Africa. It center growing concentration global capital. Under circumstances, Kingdom Saudi Arabia would important. It era Americans war ever peoples Islamic world, depend ever greater amounts imported energy, need ever larger foreign loans run government sustain life style. Yet Saudi Arabia little known. It society planet penetrated Western colonialism. No European armies breached borders; missionaries; merchants. Its capital, Riyadh, long limits infidels; holy cities Mecca Medina remain today. When Westerners finally came Saudi Arabia, came vindicators presumed cultural superiority, hired help. As result, say Saudis secretly see world's peoples divided two basic categories: (1) fellow Saudis; (2) potential employees. Be may, foreigners, Western, Asian, Arab, lived Saudi Arabia see strange place — one easy understand remains odds many values non-Saudis profess. The Kingdom long stood apart global norms. Its system government draws tribal Islamic traditions rather Western models: Its king presides rather rules royal family Saudi society. His responsibility less make decisions shape proclaim consensus, assuring share national wealth all, especially least privileged. Saudi Arabia levies taxes citizens, religious tithe known "zakat" — two-and-a-half percent annual donation private capital charity public purposes. All Saudis enjoy free education medical care birth death pursue services home abroad, wish. The Kingdom parliament, though elaborate informal mechanisms consultation citizens policy matters. Saudi Arabia reverses thereby affirms basic principle American political philosophy. "No representation without taxation." Unlike countries Arab Gulf, Saudi Arabia invested oil wealth home, abroad, though long generous foreign aid. (At one point donating six percent GDP other, mostly Muslim, nations.) The desperate poverty pre-oil period now, most, dim memory. Over lifetime elderly Saudis, Kingdom's per capita income risen one hundred fold. Sparsely populated mud-walled villages grown huge air-conditioned cities 21st Century architecture. Today, Saudis literate; many university degrees. There U.S. Ph.D.'s Saudi Cabinet Cabinet Congress put together. Despite rapid development, strong family structure characterized traditional Saudi society remained largely intact. It truly moving see lovingly children grandchildren care elders Kingdom. Saudi Arabia's unique social stability reflected fact almost none citizens emigrate, though many second homes abroad, few, like Osama Binladin, exiled deviant behavior.. For long time easier journalists academics get visa Tibet Saudi Arabia. Perhaps accounts near total lack institutions scholars study place. In United States, 9/11 followed avalanche polemical tracts, still books Kingdom reflect realities rather authors' biases propagandistic agendas. Lack personal familiarity Kingdom helps explain repeated prediction pundits Saudi monarchy jeopardy. Generations pundits passed away. The Kingdom not. When I ambassador Riyadh, I struck apparent social stasis I briefly thought national motto "progress without change." But fact change constant Saudi Arabia. Most comes top down. UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773930 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773930 Date: 08/31/2015 Not Saudis happy status quo. Some angry extent Kingdom opening reforming. Others impatient get reform. The ranks latter clearly include King Abdullah bin Abdulaziz Al-Sasud, current ruler. Now late eighties throne since 2005, surprised everyone vigor efforts modernize Saudi society reshape relationships world beyond borders. Saudi Arabia plenty problems keep king engaged. A lot issues derive peculiar religious heritage Saudi state. The current Kingdom Saudi Arabia (now century old) third political structure ally House Sa‘ud family eighteenth century religious reformer Shaykh al Islam Mohammed ibn 'Abd al-Wahhab Al-Tamimi. Ibn 'Abd al-Wahhab's writings form doctrinal basis so-called Wahhabism, notoriously intolerant socially conservative form Islam often confused reactionary religious traditions like Taliban. Saudi history involved sustained effort Kingdom's rulers persuade religious scholars puritanical followers embrace change open outside world. This struggle mainly peaceful virtually invisible outsiders. Sometimes, however, engendered violence. In 1975, example, late King Faisal paid life instituting public education girls introducing television nation. Both regent (from 1996 2005) recently ruler, King Abdullah careful avoid drama promotion change truly startling review cumulative results leadership. Take women's issues, example. In 2002, responsibility girls' education transferred religious authorities ministry education. Women make 58 percent enrollment Saudi universities. The new Princess Noura bint Abdulrahman University Women, currently construction Riyadh, enroll 40,000 students fall. Female participation labor force rising rapidly. Twenty-nine percent women work outside home. (That low figure compared represents remarkable advance Kingdom.) One-third civil service positions reserved women. The first woman took seat Council Ministers last year. After bit kerfuffie, Kingdom's religious scholars finally endorsed coeducation new King Abdullah University Science Technology. That big blow legitimacy gender apartheid. A Saudi friend I betting long women Kingdom drive. We plan clean building separate road system may require. (That's joke, hope.) A word abciut vision embodied King Abdullah University Science Technology. F6unded king last September initial endowment ten billion dollars, KAUST international, graduate-level research university. It sits two-billion-dollar campus Red Sea seventy-five miles northwest Mecca. On one level, leading element effort prepare Kingdom knowledge-based economy complement eventually supercede current reliance energy exports. But another level, powerful answer religious zealotry terrorist movements like al Qa'ida espouse. Let explain. There broad consensus among world's 1.6 billion Muslims modern age ethically corrupt religious faith needs reinvigoration renewal. Much like early Christian Protestants, many believe way achieve rediscover reaffirm values religion's earliest times. When inaugurated KAUST, King Abdullah explained envisaged reborn Bayt al-Hikma "House Wisdom." The original "House Wisdom" founded Baghdad around 760 C.E., second century Muslim era. It Arabs incorporated Greek, Indian foreign knowledge Islam conceived much modern mathematics, astronomy, medicine, chemistry, zoology, geography. It made Islamic civilization global leader science technology. The "House Wisdom" prospered age tolerance, Jews Christians served alongside Muslims ministers government. Though destroyed Mongols 1258, knowledge preserved developed eventually found way Europe, sparked Renaissance. Today, like mainstream Muslims, extremists al Qa'ida related movements argue Islam must return roots. But portray early Islam puritanical, xenophobic, intolerant, oppressive women. KAUST living rebuttal historical fallacy ideology hatred derived it. It conceived new "House Wisdom." It stands principle Islam founded reborn religious guide society open ideas traditions. It represents call return Islam tolerant foreign ways, respectful UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773930 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773930 Date: 08/31/2015 women, dedicated scientific study God's handiwork, committed development new technologies better human condition. KAUST much instrument religious renaissance answer extremism academic institution. This brings issue religious tolerance. In 2003, King Abdullah inaugurated called "national forum intellectual dialogue." This ongoing national dialogue unprecedented acceptance religious diversity Kingdom. It marks end longstanding official discrimination Shiite minority. In 2007, King Abdullah made historic call Pope Vatican, first time Muslim leader stature done so. In 2008 organized two unprecedented international interfaith conferences Muslims, Jews, Christians, Buddhists, others Madrid New York. He intends dialogue, too, continuing process. There major domestic reform initiatives progress, like complete revamping Saudi educational system curriculum, experiments elections lower levels government civil society, efforts shift Kingdom toward reliance alternative sources energy, development huge new petrochemical industry complement production energy primary form. Time permit describe developments. My point simply great deal going Saudi Arabia press pundits seem realize. That said, everything is, course, relative. Sadly, many Saudis, history nation suggests religiously uptight are, oil comes ground. The Kingdom continues many ways belie God's admonition Holy Quran "there compulsion religion." The open practice religions Islam remains banned. The status role women Saudi society controversial far settled. Despite efforts "Saudiization," foreign workers continue dominate employment market, demanding premium compensate discomfort stress Saudi Arabia's religiously sanctioned mores impose them. Methods political consultation worked cohesive less populous Saudi Arabia longer produce consensus. The fiscal basis state continues oil exports, oil commodity whose price fluctuates unpredictably. There is, words, long list problems Saudis work coming years. Let turn briefly Saudi Arabia's foreign relations reviewing state country's interaction it. In foreign even domestic affairs, King Abdullah's impact little short revolutionary. He overseen negotiated settlement Kingdom's long-disputed borders neighbors. He brought Saudi Arabia World Trade Organization, ensuring trade investment activities first time follow internationally agreed rules. In 1982, Beirut, led Arab League historic reversal policy toward Israel- Palestine issue. Saudi Arabia long insisted would last state region recognize establish relations Israel. At Beirut, King Abdullah committed first normalize relations Israel upon achievement mutually acceptable arrangement coexistence Palestinians. He persuaded Arab countries promise would same. To great frustration, Israel respond. Since then, hope two-state solution could gain acceptance Israel region dimmed. Many Saudi Arabia's foreign policy challenges stem recent American policies region. These policies effect liberating Israel constraints settlement activities belligerent intervention Arab neighbors, installing Iran dominant political influence Iraq Lebanon, consolidating rather eroding Syrian-Iranian alliance, pushing Hamas arms Iranians, raising regional tensions Tehran's nuclear program nothing effective it. Then Afghanistan, United States seems engaged crusade militant Islam — one many region fear may soon extend Yemen. Saudi counter-terrorism specialists, well-deserved international reputation effectiveness, convinced efficient way radicalize Muslim populations encourage terrorism United States foreign policy partners invade, occupy, humiliate them. They believe panicked militarism U.S. response 9/11 exactly groups like al Qa'ida hoped for. They see sign United States abandon actions policies metastasize extremism stimulate terrorist reprisal Americans foreign friends. To end, building new relationships countries like China, India, Russia, strengthening cooperation longstanding partners Europe Asia like Britain, France, Germany, Japan, south Korea. It Kingdom given United States. As king's scholarship program Saudi students country evidences, Saudi Arabia continues reach seek improved relations America. But Saudis longer trust us take interests account protect enemies. In December 2002, U.S. prepared invade Iraq forcefully expressed advice Crown Prince Abdullah, Saudi Aramco (the world's largest oil company) quietly abandoned decades-old subsidy cost shipping oil North American market. Within months, China replaced United States Kingdom's biggest overseas market oil. U.S. exports remained relatively constant Saudi Arabian economy boomed, dramatically reducing market share largest Middle Eastern market. Ironically, best element US- Saudi relationship cooperation terrorists. This task Saudis perforce learned excel. American policies ensure endless supply angry young Muslim men region, including Saudi Arabia. The United States said entered "long war." The last time so, 1947 Soviet Communism, enemy obvious, George Kennan gave us strategy, skillful American diplomacy gave us allies needed pursue it. Kennan's "long telegram" Moscow outlined comprehensive approach political, economic, cultural, military containment threat survival values posed Soviet Union. We followed outline. Forty years later, Kennan forecast, without go war USSR, Soviet enemy collapsed infirmities. This time, "long war" various Islamic extremists, tribes, sects, societies. We're quite sure enemy is. No Kennan emerged give us strategy f6r winning without fighting or, indeed, "strategy" all. instead, flailing superbly lethal military response events. Lacking strategy, unable recruit foreign partners support one. We alone Iraq. We isolated internationally Israel-Palestine issue. Our NATO allies us Afghanistan consideration NATO, think know doing. Many already announced intention withdraw. Pakistan us alternatives worse. Saudi Arabia America head al Qa'ida's enemies list. The Kingdom has, however, successfully vilified eyes American elite public. To deal effectively Islamic extremism, need Muslim allies. There none potent Kingdom Saudi Arabia. Yet made effort seek advice address challenges Islamic extremism. We sought help legitimize effective political, informational, cultural, economic strategy productive engagement Islamic world. An intensive effort reset relationship Saudi Arabia craft common antiterrorist strategy king would good place start. Original Message From: McHale, Judith A <McHaleJA@state.gov> To: H Cc: Mills, Cheryl D <MillsCD@state.gov> Sent: Sat Feb 13 03:22:40 2010 Subject: FW: Joseph Nye/The New Public Diplomacy Thought might interested piece Joe Nye I believe validates new approach trying implement. The New Public Diplomacy Joseph S. Nye <http://www.project-syndicate.org/contributor/422> 2010-02-10 CAMBRIDGE — The world traditional power politics typically whose military economy would win. In today's information age, politics also whose "story" wins. National narratives are, indeed, type currency. Governments compete organizations enhance credibility weaken opponents. Witness contest government UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773988 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773988 Date: 08/31/2015 protesters Iranian elections June 2009, Internet Twitter played crucial roles, recent controversy Google China. Reputation always mattered world politics, credibility become crucial "paradox plenty." When information plentiful, scarce resource attention. Under new conditions, soft sell may, ever, prove effective hard sell. For example, relative independence BBC, sometimes source consternation British governments, paid rich dividends credibility, illustrated account Tanzanian President Jakaya Kikwete's day: "he rises dawn, listens BBC World Service, scans Tanzanian press." Skeptics treat term "public diplomacy" mere euphemism propaganda miss point. Simple propaganda counterproductive public diplomacy. Nor public diplomacy merely public-relations campaign. Public diplomacy also involves building long-term relationships create enabling environment government policies. The contribution direct government information long-term cultural relationships varies three dimensions stages public diplomacy, three important. The first immediate dimension daily communications, involves explaining context domestic foreign-policy decisions. This dimension also involves preparation dealing crises. If vacuum information event, others rush fill it. The second dimension strategic communication, develops set simple themes, much political advertising campaign does. While first dimension measured hours days, second occurs weeks, months, even years. The third dimension public diplomacy development lasting relationships key individuals many years even decades, scholarships, exchanges, training, seminars, conferences, access media channels. These programs develop American journalist Edward R. Murrow called crucial "last three feet" — face-to- face communications, enhanced credibility reciprocity creates. But even best advertising cannot sell unpopular product. A communications strategy cannot work cuts grain policy. Actions speak louder words. All often, policymakers treat public diplomacy bandage applied damage done instruments. For example, China tried enhance soft power successfully staging 2008 Olympics, domestic simultaneous crackdown Tibet — subsequent repression Xinxiang arrests human rights lawyers — undercut gains. Great powers try use culture narrative create soft power promotes advantage, always understand it. Critics United States complain over-militarization foreign policy undercuts credibility. Instead, advocate diplomacy "on steroids," staffed diplomats trained new media, cross-cultural communications, granular local knowledge, networks contacts under-represented groups. The centralized mass-media approach public diplomacy still plays important role. Governments need correct daily misrepresentations policies, well try convey longer-term strategic message. The main strength mass-media approach audience reach ability generate public awareness set agenda. But weakness inability influence message perceived different cultural settings. The sender knows says, always targets hear. Cultural barriers apt distort heard. Networked communications, hand, take advantage two-way communications peer-to-peer relations overcome cultural differences. This type decentralization flexibility difficult governments accomplish, given central accountability structures. The greater flexibility non-governmental organizations using networks given rise call "the new public diplomacy," longer confined messaging, promotion campaigns, even direct governmental UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773988 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05773988 Date: 08/31/2015 contacts foreign publics serving foreign-policy purposes. It also building relationships civil-society actors countries facilitating networks non-governmental parties home abroad. In approach public diplomacy, government policy aimed promoting participating in, rather controlling, cross-border networks. Indeed, much government control, even appearance it, undercut credibility networks designed engender. The evolution public diplomacy one-way communications two-way dialogue treats publics co-creators meaning communication. Power global information age, ever, include soft dimension attraction well hard dimensions coercion payment. Combining dimensions effectively called "smart power." For example, current struggle transnational terrorism struggle winning hearts minds, over-reliance hard power alone path success. Public diplomacy important tool arsenal smart power, smart public diplomacy requires understanding credibility, self-criticism, role civil society generating soft power. If degenerates propaganda, public diplomacy fails convince, undercut soft power. Instead, must remain two-way process, soft power depends, first foremost, upon understanding minds others. Leslie H. Gelb must reassign Rahm, dump Larry Summers, get rid National Security adviser Jim Jones. The negative, even dismissive, talk Obama White House reached critical point. The president must change key personnel now. Unless speedily sets new team, reduced speechmaker. It's mostly matter relocating Chicago campaign crowd surround Oval Office inserting people proven records getting things done Washington world. To fair, it's clear whether bad judgments priorities, practicalities, steadiness come Mr. Obama White House team. Maybe overpowers discussions, maybe gives role policymaking far beyond experience realm. Unless you're there, don't know. But Mr. Obama president, except right-wing crazies, Americans still recognize great talents promise. It who's got helped. So who've got go. It who's got helped. So who've got go. One may quarrel sense urgency here. But it's hard conversation opinion leaders anywhere— especially Washington—that doesn't descend ripping Obama's White House team. The refrain complaints always same: • Obama forever taking strong stances backfill trim. Most recently, said "begrudge" Wall Streeters big earnings part market system. This, face saying couple weeks ago big bonuses "shameful." • Obama doesn't know what's really going on. Regarding Middle East, recently said "I think absolutely true year didn't produce kind breakthrough wanted, anticipated political problems sides earlier, might raised expectations high." He totally realize Palestinians Israelis nowhere close sitting dealing. • Obama wants get along everyone badly doesn't recognize real opposition sees it—let alone know deal it. He emerges meeting congressional Republican leaders health-care reform says "an eternal optimist"—when Republican leaders told press don't see common ground believe administration "scrap bill start over." • It's even hard follow latest Afghan policy. He calls Afghanistan "war necessity" orders 30,000 new troops there, coupled announcement he'll begin withdrawing year plus, see advisers say start withdrawals say won't. And last week The Financial Times, Edward Luce provided <http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/b6b4700a-10fb-lldf-9a9e-00144feab49a.html> thunderclap Washington's negative consensus incompetence Obama's Chicago-laden team. Luce named names White House, number journalists bloggers strikingly failed link Luce story. They said fear wrath Chicagoans. Steve Clemons, author The Washington Note, essentially endorsed <http://www.thewashingtonnote.com/archives/2010/02/core_chicago_teh Luce finding slapped fellow bloggers' wrists hiding issue. The situation serious Carter administration. There, two capable political campaigners—Hamilton Jordan Jody Powell—moved critical White House positions without knowing much business Washington. And were, quite naturally, busy learn. They also added "them" versus "us" (Washington insiders bureaucrats versus regular guys Georgia) mentality plagues administrations. The Chicagoans others "guarding" president create "us versus them" world. It's hard imagine policy conversation president Chicago crowd, since none them, except Rahm Emanuel, Washington policy experience. And isn't much evidence bring strong-minded outsiders challenge president regular basis either. The result inexperienced president advised inexperienced team. Here personnel changes bruited political policy circles: First, remove Rahm Emanuel chief staff move senior political adviser slot. No one I've talked believes management skills discipline run White House. But terrific political mind fighter given new job time thing. Proven pros could step right include following: Erskine Bowles, president University North Carolina former Clinton chief staff; Leon Panetta, CIA director formerly White House chief well Clinton; Sylvia Mathews, former deputy chief staff also Clinton; John Podesta, another former Clinton chief heads Center American Progress. All four tough know manage. Replace Lawrence Summers, director White House's National Economic Council, Paul Volcker, former chairman Federal Reserve. Summers brilliant highly controversial; he's beaten said want anyway. Volcker unmatched stature, practical experience, courage lion. He one position get step-by-step brass tacks economy stop Mr. Obama's weekly gyrations. Others proven track records help inside outside advisers are: Stephen Robert, formerly head Oppenheimer, Vincent Mai, former leader AEA Investors, Tom Hill Blackstone. There also two economic stars Washington who'd improve policymaking public combat: Sheila Bair, chairwoman Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Elizabeth Warren, chair Congressional Oversight Panel. One outside adviser would help president see economic hard choices ahead: Peter G. Peterson, accomplished businessman policy head. David Axelrod, senior political adviser president, needs concentrate next presidential campaign, wherein expertise lies, domestic foreign policy, another smart unknowledgeable voice. Good replacements know politics Washington would aforementioned Podesta; Tom Daschle, former Democratic Senate Majority Leader. As David Plouffe, another senior campaign aide, unofficial residence White House, lodged nearby Executive Office Building. Senior adviser Chicago buddy Valerie Jarrett much part inner circle move, given limited role making policy. Mr. Obama's crowd appears think getting things done means giving another speech. It's nice, nearly enough. Robert Gibbs needs rest press secretary. Let's put way: He wasn't born daily jousts pithy Republicans. His job calls memorable pointed phrases attacks, circle-the-wagon circumlocutions. Possible successors? Try Doyle McManus L.A. Times, Jake Tapper ABC News, Helene Cooper The New York Times. Last least, James Jones, National Security Adviser, move on. The career Marine greatly admired respected Commandant Corps NATO's military chief. He handled duties great skill. But wide acclamation inside outside White House, emerged strategist—perhaps key requirement key position. The person job pull everything together—laying achievable objectives precise plans dispense carefully packaged carrots sticks. One Democrat could step now, despite age, Zbigniew Brzezinski, Jimmy Carter's national-security adviser. He first-rate strategic mind—a rare quality—and knows deliver results. Obama need iron Zbig's lack sympathy toward Israel Russia. "My friends White House would agree this, lost narrative," Mr Podesta said interview View DC, Financial Times' video series Washington. "Clearly needs one speech while: UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05774069 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05774069 Date: 08/31/2015 needs, I think, constantly reinforced. And president, entire team ... He's got terrific cabinet. Use it. Get country use it." Mr Podesta, also chief staff Bill Clinton, drew parallels former president's difficulties first two years, culminated 1994 Republican takeover Congress following failure healthcare reform. When asked whether failure latest attempt healthcare reform would result similar electoral "massacre" Democratic party mid-term elections November, said: "I subscribe view." Mr Podesta founded Centre American Progress, Washington's largest liberal think-tank, often described "government-in-exile" years George W. Bush White House. He said Mr Obama three options healthcare reform. First, try enact whole thing using budget reconciliation process, would enable pass 51 votes. The Democrats lost controlling 60-seat super-majority last month election defeat Massachusetts. The second would pass watered bill Republican support. The third would abandon attempt, Mr Clinton 1993. Mr Podesta, Mr Obama still regularly consults, said still better 50:50 chance getting reform through. "The worst option among three nothing, they're going figure track viable," said. "It may mean Democratic votes. But such, it." He painted fairly bleak view overall health US politics. "It sucks," said. Pointing strategy obstructionism Republican lawmakers, said: "I think president trying re-engage Republicans, but, quite frankly, he's dealing party [Abraham] Lincoln. He's dealing party [Sarah] Palin." The growth partisanship increasing difficulty getting big reforms Senate threatening turn US into, "in essence, parliamentary system without majority rule", opposition automatically opposes serious initiatives. The political stasis California provided writing wall US whole, said. Since 1978 passage Proposition 13 state, budget changes required two-thirds majority. "And nothing gets done." From: Howard, Ariel Sent: Wednesday, March 31, 2010 4:11 PM To: Schwartz, Larry Subject: Strategic Dialogue Press Coverage (3/22 - 3/31) U.S.-Pakistan Strategic Dialogue Media Summary The U.S.-Pakistan Strategic Dialogue dominated Pakistani media March 24 March 25. All major English Urdu language networks carried live Secretary Foreign Minister Qureshi's remarks opening session. On Thursday morning, nearly television networks led coverage joint press availability. All major English Urdu language dailies featured talks front pages, highlighting Secretary's announcement $125 million aid Pakistan's energy sector. Reporting straight-forward favorable headlines: Dawn—"U.S, Pakistan pledge boost broaden ties" "U.S. provide $125m energy, power plants"; The News—"US vows boost energy, defence, trade ties"; Nawa-i-Waqt—"U.S. neither abandon dictate Pakistan"; The Nation—"New day' US, Pakistan: Hillary." Media highlighted positive shift U.S.-Pakistan relations, echoing Secretary Clinton's statement talks beginning new chapter. Reports also focused question nuclear cooperation U.S. engagement Kashmir dispute; however U.S. position issues widely reported media prior Dialogue. The Nation published editorial, entitled "Negative starting note," criticizing talks began. The daily stated "promises made issues, including nuclear cooperation, see fruition." Other editorials stressed need sustained commitment sides, beyond March 24, produce results: Dawn –"Prospects Pak-US ties," Daily Times—"Pak-US Strategic Dialogue." End Summary. It's frugality; he's trying avoid poisoned. You can't careful: leaving house, also straps Smith & Wesson 9mm handgun holster secreted depths robes. Seized occasional fits passion, Jabar known whip gun meetings. He may jumpy, tactics like entirely place line work: district governor, 65-year-old unenviable task — wresting Arghandab River Valley, one dangerous places Afghanistan <http://www.ft.com/world/asiapacific/afghanistan>, Taliban. Viewed roof Jabar's district headquarters, sweep valley beautiful — bleakly majestic - charged menace. A distant range low, dun-coloured hills defines valley's opposite flank. Orchards pomegranate trees, branches stripped bare cold, line banks river meandering across valley floor, dividing east side Arghandab west. The district governor's office The east Jabar's office perched, US troops feel safer — it's west side call "bad juju land". Insurgents use strip desert infiltrate Kandahar, birthplace Taliban mid-1990s, pivot previous Afghan wars turned. Roadside bombs hidden lush vineyards last year turned Arghandab killing field. A battalion 82nd Airborne Division deployed mid-December hoping better luck, new showdown coming. Stanley McChrystal <http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/30b0c4d8-091f-11df-ba88- 00144feabdc0.html> , Nato commander Afghanistan, vowed secure Kandahar. The Taliban want back. One night, one insurgents called governor's mobile. "He said, `I'm going kill you, you're working Americans," says Jabar, sitting carpet office. "I said, 'Do whatever do.' Then I abused hung up." Jabar normally cuts rather solemn figure. At -recollection, laughed. Aside 2-508 battalion 82nd Airborne, two Americans arrived <http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/6f824828-183b-11df-9256-00144feab49a.html> Arghandab help out: 27-year-old Kevin Melton 35-year-old Christopher Harich. They're part Obama administration's "civilian surge <http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/ee3ee108-d60f-11de-b8Of-00144feabdc0.html> ", announced alongside fresh build-up US troops. Working whitewashed, two-storey district office, unlikely trio aims turn tide opinion district. They must spring, valley come leaf Taliban fighters return Pakistan time fighting season. "Arghandab gate Kandahar city," Jabar says. "If Arghandab lost, Kandahar also lost. It's important valley Afghanistan." Haji Abdul Jabar Kevin Melton US Aid Arghandab Valley Jabar, Harich Melton little common beards. Melton, grew suburbs Washington, working USAid, US government's development agency <http://www.usaid.gov/> . "It's physically, mentally, emotionally intellectually exhausting." Harich lawyer former marine Louisiana recently worked policy adviser governor West Virginia. "They're saying, 'I come somebody something. This government about: I air grievances somebody Taliban.'" And yet Jabar first admit writ run much -further building. Vehicles night patrol It tempting measure progress west's war Afghanistan terms damage Taliban — whether capturing movement's leaders driving back fighters battlefield. Last month, headlines dominated arrest Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar <http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f4f14de4-1b09-11df-88fa- 00144feab49a.html> , Taliban's second-in-command, big Nato offensive town Marjah <http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c8d82998:1411-11df-8847-00144feab49a.html> . But even Mullah Baradars arrested, military pushes launched, Taliban may simply bide time exploiting alienation corrupt absent government. The way stop undertake painstaking work stitching together government capable providing security services "shadow governments" set insurgents. Western countries talking years, course, building governance Afghanistan, men Melton Harich represent renewed commitment. US officials say 900 US civilian officers active Afghanistan, compared 300 start 2009, 50 destined Kandahar province. The hope team deliver one-two punch long seemed elusive exploiting military victories nurture functioning local government. The demands seemed reasonable enough Harich immediately acquiesce. Part job using Americans' ability open close aid taps get Jabar live vision impartial, honest governor. UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05774593 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05774593 Date: 08/31/2015 Like much Afghanistan's political class, Jabar's "legitimacy" comes role Mujahideen fighter 1980s, battling Soviet -invaders. (Arghandab witnessed heavy fighting: Russians mounted month-long siege never took valley.) Although governors Afghanistan's 34 provinces power — theory — nominate district governors, US intelligence officers say Jabar owes pre-eminence backing Karimullah, young leader Alakozai, ethnic Pashtun sub-tribe dominant valley. Said Amir Mohammad Agha, whose refusal recognise Jabar's authority keeps valley divided Divisions clans mean Jabar means consensus candidate. In particular, Said Amir Mohammad Agha <http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/54cf9eca-10e5-11df-9a9e-00144feab49a.html> , single-most influential man west side river, resents him. US officers say Agha detained Guantanamo Bay suspected Taliban commander. As long Agha refuses recognise Jabar's authority, valley remain divided. Even east side, frustration Melton Harich, Jabar yet prove garner much legitimacy. Locals milling around office mutter accusations skims salaries district officials turn work steers US reconstruction contracts towards friends. "He's good man, wants money bribes," said one, reflecting comments several visitors. Jabar vigorously denies allegations — indeed, linked one pistol-waving incident meeting Americans. Yet behaviour would unusual Afghanistan, bribery lubricates patronage-based system Karzai past leaders used hold ethnically diverse country together. The dilemma runs entire project Afghanistan. Western officials want impose template efficient administration, little choice work leaders rely traditional system survive. In Kandahar, dilemma acute. Afghanistan's centralised system means Jabar dependent provincial government based city send officers fill largely empty building, materialised. Indeed, Alakozai elders believe rivals Karzai's Popalzai tribe exploiting official positions Kandahar accumulate political economic influence expense. There deeper tension. Assessing hard even venturing valley potentially life-threatening undertaking. "If looks wrong smells wrong, -probably wrong." UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05774593 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05774593 Date: 08/31/2015 From bullet-proof window, procession mud homes seem grow organically valley floor rolled past. A weeks before, man pulled pistol shot wounded two Afghan policemen near road. These days, insurgents targeting foot patrols make dangerous try build rapport locals. Sgt Donny Kuehner takes tea Haji Jhapour At US outpost village called Sakari Bagh, Sergeant Donny -Kuehner, 23-year-old southern California, led patrol bazaar ramshackle stalls selling blotchy bunches bananas dangling strings stacked cans Power Stag — "World's Finest Quality Motor Oil". Removing helmet, Kuehner entered petrol station owned Haji Jhapour—the unofficial king bazaar whose assistant served green tea. An Afghan policeman wearing mascara yellow bandana round neck joined circle two men talked, via interpreter. "How people bazaar feel us here?" Kuehner asked. "The people bazaar good people, they're busy business," Jhapour replied. "You heard anything lately kind Taliban anywhere, anything?" Kuehner asked. "I'm busy business, I don't time follow Taliban — job police," Jhapour said, gesturing man mascara. "When people come buy petrol I sometimes hear news. If I hear anything, I'll let know." As walked back base, Kuehner confessed hard know local loyalties lay. Some labourers busy filling barriers earth build outpost's defences beaten Taliban fighters. "The locals key this," Kuehner said. "Getting side — could — would leaps bounds now." Such ambiguous encounters stuff daily grind counter-insurgency, building relationships critical. After gradually -adopting approach fight insurgency Iraq, US military honing skills Afghanistan. But clear soldiers much: unless viable government emerges, presence scant lasting impact. Barack Obama careful downplay suggestions <http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/5f6ce026-df6d-11de-98ca- 00144feab49a.html> , though Arghandab, -distinction blurry. May 6, 2010, 6:11 amlt's Not About Greece AnymoreBy PETER BOONE AND SIMON JOHNSONLouisa Gouliamaki/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images Protesters waved flags Acropolis archaeological site behind banners English Greek hung front Parthenon temple Athens.Peter Boone chairman charity Effective Intervention research associate Center Economic Performance London School Economics. He also principal Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson, former chief economist International Monetary Fund, co-author "13 Bankers."The Greek "rescue" package announced last weekend dramatic, unprecedented far enough stabilize euro zone.The Greek government European Union leadership, prodded International Monetary Fund, 'finally becoming realistic dire economic situation Greece. They abandoned previous rounds optimistic forecasts admitted profoundly worse situation. This new program calls "fiscal adjustments" — cuts fiscal deficit, mostly spending cuts — totaling 11 percent gross domestic product 2010, 4.3 percent 2011, 2 percent 2012 2013. The total debt-to-G.D.P. ratio peaks 149 percent 2012-13 starting gentle glide path back sanity.This new program honest enough show unlikely succeed.Daniel Gros, eminent economist euro zone issues based Brussels, argued 1 percent G.D.P. decline Greek government spending, total demand country falls 2.5 percent G.D.P. If government reduces spending 15 percent G.D.P. — initial shock demand could well 30 percent G.D.P.Obviously simple rule work large numbers, illustrates Greece likely experience sharp recession — substantial uncertainty around bad economy get. The program announced last weekend assumes Greek G.D.P. falls 4 percent year, another 2.6 percent 2011, recovering positive growth 2012 beyond.Such figures seem extremely optimistic, particularly face civil unrest sweeping Greece deep hostility expressed toward UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05774734 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05774734 Date: 08/31/2015 Greece northern European policy circles.The pattern growth critical because, program, Greece needs grow debt problem soon. Greece's debt-to-G.D.P. ratio debilitating 145 percent end 2011.Now consider putting realistic growth figures I.M.F. forecast Greece's economy — e.g., G.D.P. declining 12 percent 2011, debt-to-G.D.P. ratio may reach 155 percent. At levels, 5 percent real interest rate growth, country needs primary surplus 8 percent G.D.P. keep debt-to- G.D.P. ratio stable. It nowhere near level. The I.M.F. program Greece running primary budget deficit around 1 percent G.D.P. year, assumes path Greek growth regarded "upside scenario."The politics implied budget surpluses remains brutal. Since Greek debt held abroad, roughly 80 percent budget savings Greek government makes go straight Germans, French foreign debt holders (mostly banks). If growth turns poorly, Greeks prepared ever-tougher austerity pay Germans? Even everything goes well, Greek citizens seem unlikely welcome version "new normal." Last week European leadership panicked — late day — realized euro zone risk meltdown. If euro zone proves unwilling protect member like Greece default, bond investors run Portugal Spain also — doubt this, study carefully interlocking debt picture published recently The New York Times. Higher yields government debt would caused concerns potential bank runs nations, spread nations Europe.When "run," clear stops. In hazy distance, Belgium, France, Austria many others potentially risk. Even Germans cannot afford bail nations.Slapped face ugly scenario, Europeans decided throw everything I.M.F. bailing Greece. The program announced small chance preventing eventual Greek bankruptcy, may still slow avert dangerous spiral downward — enormous collateral damage — rest Europe.The I.M.F. floated fashion alternative scenario debt restructuring, rejected European Union Greek authorities. This surprise; leading European policy makers completely unprepared broader problems would follow Greek "restructuring," markets would immediately mark debt (i.e., increase yields) Portugal, Spain, Ireland even Italy.The fear panic face would unparalleled modern times: When Greeks pay 50 percent face value debt, investors expect Portuguese Spanish? It becomes arbitrary, including countries dragged down.Someone decide defended cost, European structures completely unsuited kind tough decision-making pressurein extreme downside scenario, Germany obvious safe haven within euro zone, government bond yields would collapse governments face sharply rising yields. The euro zone would likely hold together.There still narrow escape path, without immediate debt default chaos would produce:• Talk euro — moving toward parity American dollar would help lift growth across euroz one.• As euro falls, bond yields rise euro zone periphery. This create episodes panic. Enough short-term financing must place support rollover government debt. Once euro fallen great deal, announce European Central Bank support euro levels (i.e., prevent appreciation, G-20 tacit agreement), also support peripheral euro zone nations viewed solvent buying bonds whenever markets chaotic. At stage, before, euro zone leadership needs push weaker governments restructure. That include Greece perhaps also Portugal. Hopefully, scenario Spain muddle through. European banks recapitalized necessary management replaced. This massive failure euro groupthink — including notably political level — question bank executives behaved responsibly long replaced en masse.To extent possible, ensuing losses shared bank creditors. But careful wish for. The bankers powerful reason; built vital yet fragile structures heart economies. Dismantle care. T Original Message From: Sullivan, Jacob J <SullivanJJ@state.gov> To: H Sent: Fri Apr 02 12:34:19 2010 Subject: FW: Economist: The limits freedom faith See piece defamation religion. Not bad. http://www.economist.com/world/international/displaystory.cfm?story_id=15833005 Religion human rights The limits freedom faith Mar 31st 2010 From The Economist print edition Opponents bid Muslim states "protect religion" claim small success How dare call us blasphemers? IT DOES happen often: Christian lobbyists, sort favour prayer American classrooms crucifixes Italian ones, lining side secularists battle curb religion's role public square. But camps quiet satisfaction recent vote United Nations. Not outcome, slim margin defeat. On March 25th Human Rights Council (HRC), Geneva-based UN agency often exasperates Western members, voted 20 votes 17, eight abstentions, text lists "defamation religion" infringement liberty. Nothing amazing there: Organisation Islamic Conference (01C), groups 56 mainly Muslim states (plus Palestine), working push resolutions kind General Assembly UN bodies since 2005. But margin smallest ever, opponents think could good chance defeating "defamation" motion next time one comes around. UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05774767 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05774767 Date: 08/31/2015 The OIC's idea establish principle faiths need protection, individuals do. It denies sinister intention (see article <http://www.economist.com/world/international/displaystory.cfm?story_id=15833035> ). And ears, OIC's effort sounds like harmless UN-speak, nothing more. (The United States Commission International Religious Freedom, congressionally mandated body, noted logical flaw: defamation means harming reputation living person entity: implies one can't defame idea religious founder longer, least physically, alive earth.) But critics OIC campaign, include atheists, Christians indeed Muslims, say "defamation" idea worse hot air: far protecting human rights, emboldens countries use blasphemy laws criminalise dissent. What encourages critics countries seem coming around view. Mexico, Uruguay, Argentina, Zambia South Korea voted latest resolution. Brazil criticised text abstained. Deeper still inside UN's bureaucracy, another battle religion rages—and stakes could even higher. An "ad hoc committee" mulling ways amend extend UN convention racial discrimination. Certain states want language would fuse categories race faith; want new convention, protocol existing one. For secularists (in broad sense people, including believers, oppose idea faith privileged access power), alarming. Non-binding resolutions defamation bad enough; UN treaty race-plus- religion would legal force, least signatories, give heart theocrats. At HRC's latest discussion effort March, Algerian oversees project keen plough ahead. But countries like Switzerland, Japan, Mexico, Argentina France retorted would better enforce existing UN norms dream new ones. Efforts widen racism accord resume, new chairman, late year—but critics relieved stalled it. Still, would-be theocrats may focus harder adding racism charter, face real risk defeated defamation, view Roy Brown, Geneva spokesman International Humanist Ethical Union. Meanwhile Christian-inspired NGO, European Centre Law Justice, denouncing abuse blasphemy laws many OIC member states. How fair point? It easy case make, example, Pakistan. Some 41 complaints blasphemy registered police Pakistan last year, says country's independent Human Rights Commission. In theory, blasphemy punishable death—a penalty handed never carried out. Worst-hit law minorities like Christians Ahmadis, group whose claim Muslim rejected Pakistani state. Although abuse law less rife 1980s, Islamist general tightened rules, law still invoked disputes (over property, say) nothing faith. "The vulnerable people, religious minorities, continue charged blasphemy," said All Dayan Hasan, researcher Human Rights Watch, campaign group. "But people convicted? No. Rarely. It used instrument political social coercion." When convictions occur, lead long jail terms; pre-trial detention last years. Pakistan's parliament revising constitution left intact religious bits, despite vow ruling party review blasphemy laws. (Indonesia stepped back move liberalise blasphemy regime.) On Pakistani streets, law dire effects. In January 2009, village Punjab province, five Ahmadis, labourer four children, charged blasphemy. They supposedly written "Prophet Muhammad" wall mosque toilet. The children behind bars nearly six months till charge quashed. And last September young Pakistani Christian accused throwing part Koran drain. It seems real crime, however, affection Muslim woman. A mob torched church, many Christians flee. From Foster Care To Law School Graduate, Howard University Student Beats The Odds Jelani Freeman lived 6 foster homes 10 years Updated: Friday, 07 May 2010, 8:25 PM EDT Published : Friday, 07 May 2010, 7:55 PM EDT By BETH PARKER/myfoxdc WASHINGTON - Jelani Freeman gone lot wear robe. This weekend, graduate Howard University Law School. He remembers shaky foundation young life. A mother could take care him. He lived six foster homes ten years. "Moving different homes. The kids like 'you weren't yesterday.' Where's mom at?" said Freeman. At 18 years old, left system went college search room board. He knew people expected kids foster care system - much. "All I would hear jail homeless weren't well," said Freeman. He beat odds graduated, felt ... alone. "I distinctly remember walking across stage undergrad. You know graduation everyone cheer section yells walk across stage almost silence I walked across," said Freeman. It different time. When Freeman gets diploma Saturday convention center, 26 people - friends supporters far away California - D.C. show support. Freeman also got boost internship program kids spent time foster care. He placed office Senator Hillary Clinton. Clinton even mentions updated version book "It Takes A Village." Now, may use law degree work public policy - especially children's issues. He wants kids know: "There's bright future stay focused work hard." He living proof difference make. UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05774847 Date: 08/31/2015
