Joseph Stiglitz, Nobel prizewinner predicted global crisis, delivers verdict Chancellor's first Budget tells Paul Vallely take UK deeper recession hit millions — poorest — badly Sunday, 27 June 2010 George Osborne probably bothered man thinks got last week's emergency Budget almost entirely wrong. But be. Because man former chief economist World Bank won Nobel Prize Economics work markets produce outcomes which, theory, ought to. Professor Joseph Stiglitz, described biggest brain economics, distinctly unimpressed George Osborne's strategy. This, predicts, make Britain's recovery recession longer, slower harder needs be. The rise VAT could even tip us double-dip recession. Stiglitz, Bill Clinton's senior economic adviser, professor economics finance Columbia Business School. He UK week University Manchester, chairs Brooks World Poverty Institute, lifted head detail international development scrutinise economic strategy Conservative Chancellor whose Liberal Democrat partners recently reversed judgement massive public spending cuts would endanger economy joined Tory slash-and-burn strategy. They deeply wrong so, believes. It would mistake ignore Stiglitz this. He track record getting predictions right. He one economists predicted global financial meltdown long occurred. "What happened much accord I expected," tells meet coffee outside Blackwell bookshop centre university. "The data pretty clear that." And scale crash? "That wasn't surprise," adds, matter-of-fact manner. "The bigger bubble, bigger burst. "The thing economists fully grasp extent banks engaged murky risk-taking activities. They taking risk money, shareholders' money, bond-holders' money," says. Banks demanding 40 per cent corporate profits, saying innovative financing adding value. But "all talk innovation sham" relate real increase economy's productivity, says. "There prima facie case something screwy going [with the] perverse incentives would lead take excessive risk. But way anyone could know believe banks [conducting themselves] level stupidity. I predicted going collapse information asymmetry problems created." His Nobel prize given exactly — showing markets fail different people hold different levels information. Yet hint I-told-you-so Stiglitz's tone asks waiter coffee. He orders decaffeinated, suggests British economy needs opposite: stiff stimulant rather "fiscal consolidation" George Osborne's economic euphemism cuts. Fiscal stimulus fashion now. World leaders embarked strategy — injecting money re-energise economy — banking crash three years ago. It widely perceived worked money governments pumped banks passed ailing businesses individuals trouble mortgages. "The problem that, US, stimulus wasn't big enough," says. "Too much tax cuts. And gave money banks gave wrong banks and, result, credit restored — expect couple million homes repossessed year last year — economy UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05777221 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05777221 Date: 08/31/2015 restarted." Instead producing consensus government done more, created disillusion government anything, Stiglitz says. The result that, following attacks financial markets Greece Spain, everybody mood retrenchment. "It's pre-Keynesian, it's Hooverite," says. By means governments refusing stimulate, making cuts, Herbert Hoover US 1929 — turned Wall Street Crash Great Depression. "Hoover idea that, whenever go recession, deficits grow, decided go cuts — foolish financial markets got us trouble first place want." It become new received wisdom throughout Europe. But classic error made confuse household's economics national economy. "If household can't pay debts, tell cut back spending free cash pay debts. But national economy, cut back spending, economic activity goes down, nobody invests, amount tax take goes down, amount pay unemployment benefits goes — don't enough money pay debts. "The old story still true: cut expenditures economy goes down. We lots experiments show this, thanks Herbert Hoover IMF," adds. The IMF imposed mistaken policy Korea, Thailand, Indonesia, Argentina hosts developing countries 1980s 1990s. "So know happen: economies get weaker, investment get stymied it's downward vicious spiral. How far don't know — could Japanese malaise. Japan experiment like 1997; recovering, raised VAT went another recession." Then learned that? Because politicians like George Osborne driven ideology; national deficit excuse shrink state wanted anyway. Because financial market cares one thing — getting repaid. And European governments panicking market's wild attack Greece Spain, don't want next. "But cutbacks Germany, Britain France mean Europe suffer. The cuts feed back negatively. And everyone follows policy, budget deficits get worse, make cuts raise taxes more. It's vicious downward spiral. We're looking long, hard, slow recovery possibility double dip everybody cuts back time. The best scenario long hard ... worst much worse. If one countries forced default, banking system highly leveraged could cause real problems. This really risky, really scary." So doing? "The lesson cut back spending, redirect it. You cut war Afghanistan. You cut couple hundred billion dollars wasteful military expenditure. You cut oil subsidies. There's long list things cut. But increase spending areas, research development, infrastructure, education" — areas government get good return investment public money. "I haven't done calculation Britain, but, US, need return government investment 5 6 per cent long-term deficit debt lowered." Taxes also need restructured. Osborne increased capital gains tax high earners 18 28 per cent. "There's absolutely reason couldn't tax speculative gains [from rising house land prices] 40 per cent. There's social return land going whether people speculated not. But lower tax investment things like R&D." Stiglitz one practical solution offer. Governments set banks restart lending businesses save struggling homeowners repossession. "If banks aren't lending, let's create new lending facility job," says. "In US, gave $700bn banks; used fraction create new bank, could financed lending needed." Indeed, could done far less. "Take $100bn, lever 10 1 [by attracting funds private sector] that's trillion-dollar new lending capacity — real economy needs." Such move would help ordinary people Osborne's rhetoric tough fair. Stiglitz sceptical, too, moral underpinning Budget claims "we together", hits poorest hardest. Analysis Institute Fiscal Studies suggested Chancellor's Budget cost poor 2.5 per cent income, rich lose 1 per cent. "I've made independent study point, cuts public services disproportionate effect poor," Stiglitz says. Osborne's Budget "may well- UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05777221 Date: 08/31/2015 UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05777221 Date: 08/31/2015 intentioned, takes enormous amount work make sure package public spending cuts magnitude doesn't hit poor disproportionately". His big fear overseas aid, protected first round cuts, escape second. "Developing countries redirected towards Asia, China particular, recent years, growth Africa robust one might expected, given severity downturn," says. Even so, aid remains vital poor countries. "If aid cut back, growth badly affected," says. "China providing aid, aid infrastructure, whereas aid US Europe mainly education health - areas ordinary people suffer cuts." Joseph Stiglitz come full circle. What world needs — developing developed — retrenchment greater economic stimulus. It message many mood hear. But didn't listen last time, either. And turned right, wrong — cost us all. UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05777221 Date: 08/31/2015
